awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Microplastic filtration from active waterways
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of a portable microplastic measuring and sequestration device. Every year approximately 8 million tons of plastic enter US waterways, of which 80% gets transported in polluted rivers as both macroplastics (above 5 mm in size) and microplastics (below 5 mm in size). Microplastics are rapidly becoming a global concern, as they can easily be ingested, introducing potentially hazardous and carcinogenic additives into the diets of wildlife and humans. Currently, there are no consistent protocols available for the accurate and systematic recording of microplastic pollutant concentrations in water. Furthermore, there is also no existing technology available to sequester microplastics from tributaries, effluent streams, reservoirs, and lakes. This technology could be used by aquatic emissions research organizations and municipal riverkeepers, as it may provide them with a universal tool for microplastic monitoring and sequestration. Additionally, this device can be deployed as part of wastewater and drinking water treatment infrastructure, to potentially remove microplastics from aquatic environments. Finally, this technology could allow extracted microplastic collected from the device to be upcycled and reused, creating a circular economy for microplastic waste.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a proprietary filtration technology with the potential to physically entrap microplastic sediments from active waterways. This technology is uniquely designed to efficiently sequester microplastics from rivers and effluent streams without potentially disrupting local ecosystems. Unlike fine mesh nets that can easily get clogged with algae, slow down river flow, and entrap aquatic wildlife, this device uses a patented ‘artificial root’ biofilter to entrap microplastics. This biofilter is a dense mesh of fibers that physically ensnare sediment in the upper strata of a river’s water column, which is where almost all microplastic is found. When submerged in water, this network hosts bacteria that produce sticky biofilms that can further adhere small aquatic sediments like microplastics. The network, while dense, is uneven and has openings that allow for the transit of small aquatic organisms. Each biofilter is attached to a removable pad, making it easy to swap biofilters once they become saturated. Each pad is housed within a hydrodynamic flotation frame, aimed to allow the device to be deployed in both rivers, streams, and reservoirs. Due to it having no mechanical components, this technology operates passively, requires no electricity, and demands minimal maintenance to operate effectively. This could make the device cheaper to produce, deploy and maintain compared to the existing microplastic filtration systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2010 alone, between 4 to 12 million metric tons of plastic waste entered the world’s oceans (Jambek et al., 2015). Rivers play a significant role in carrying this plastic to the ocean, with more than 1,000 rivers accounting for 80% of annual emissions to oceans (Meijer et al., 2021). This larger, plastic debris degrades into infinitely smaller fragments, known as microplastics, that are nearly invisible to the naked eye. Microplastics are rapidly becoming a global concern, as they can easily be ingested, introducing potentially hazardous additives into the diets of wildlife and humans. Additionally, due to their small size, they are incredibly difficult to remove from water bodies without significantly disrupting aquatic ecosystems. Microplastic concentrations in rivers and drinking water are on the rise, yet no systems can affordably and systematically remove them before they enter the ocean and drinking water sources.

 

In response to this need, our team, PolyGone Systems, has been on a mission to remove the trillions of potentially harmful microplastics entering the world's oceans and drinking water. As a cleantech company spun out from Princeton University thesis research, we have innovated the world’s first affordable, portable, and environmentally-friendly microplastic filtration system, the Artificial Root. Our proprietary filter is designed to remove microplastics from wastewater, drinking water, open streams, mouths of rivers, marinas, and the outflows of lakes. Currently, our team is validating our technology through both a series of lab experiments and field deployments of a quarter-scale prototype.

 

Before developing our technology further however, our team hoped to gain a better understanding of our customer base, their specific needs, and whether our technology needs to pivot in order to better serve them. Attending the Northeast Regional NSF I-Corps program, our team learned more about the structure of the water treatment industry, and we solidified a working relationship with the Atlantic County Utility Authority (ACUA) to pilot our technology at their wastewater treatment facility in 2024. However, our team was still unsure of the needs of private drinking water and bottled water companies and had yet to conduct interviews with them. Therefore, our team attended the National NSF I-Corps program to gain a better understanding of the potential broader applications of our technology and the relationships of the relevant players within our industry ecosystem.

 

During the National I-Corps program, members from our team attended six major conferences around the world in the United Kingdom, Spain, Louisiana, Washington state, Ohio, and South Korea. We conducted 140 interviews with industry professionals, learning more about our technology’s applicability, building potential partnerships, and the drinking water industry ecosystem. We also held virtual meetings with partners, potential and current funders, public audiences, and government officials to share our technology, collaborate, educate, and pitch our company. Our most significant key learning resulting from this research was the interest in our device as a water quality monitoring tool in addition to its use in microplastic removal. Researchers in ecology, environmental science and engineering, and chemical engineering emerged as a very viable new customer base for which to expand our business model.

 

Since the program ceased, we have expanded our team, hiring nine new staff members in media, research and development, and communications from October 2022 to present. Five are women and seven identify as a person of color. We additionally went on several site visits for our full-scale pilot tests and small-scale field deployments. Ultimately, we were able to secure two full-scale pilot tests in Atlantic City, NJ and Canada that are now actively underway. Lastly, we made new strides in our public education efforts. Our team was accepted to showcase a representation of our work, ‘Tides of Plastic,” at the Hong Kong-Shenzhen Bi-City Biennale of Urbanism/Architecture, an international showcase of designers reimagining the future of urban issues that educated over 10,000 citizens on the severity of microplastic pollution and the need for action.

 

Our anticipated next steps will be conducted in three major phases. In our current and continued validation phase, we will provide proof of concept through full-scale pilot deployments at the Atlantic County Utilities Authority wastewater treatment facility and in the Canadian experimental lakes region in collaboration with the University of Toronto. Working in each of these unique water channels, we will gain critical data for refining our technology in preparation for commercialization. Additionally, we will continue to participate in expos, conferences, and establish a citizen science program through our grant award from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to raise awareness around microplastic pollution and foster community involvement. Next, we will phase in domestic expansion and commercialize our refined product for water treatment facilities and river channels. We also plan to develop a comprehensive data platform for documenting the extent and concentration of microplastic pollution globally to inform policymakers, stakeholders, and the public.
